courses.subject: SLPA
courses.title: Professional Development and Ethics I
courses.description: Speech therapy is more than just clinical skills and practice. A competent speech therapist should understand the range of professional issues related to speech-language pathology which may contribute and influence their clinical practice, decision making as well as the profession. Professional issues, ethical principles and practice are introduced and illustrated by the use of case studies and discussions. Students are also introduced to applying the range of principles to ethical practice and decision making.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to understand the concept of professional development and ethics
courses.course_syllabus: The course outline, including the course syllabus, will be provided to students in their first week of attendance in this course.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are encouraged to communicate with the instructors to provide comments and/or feedback on the course. Students are requested to participate in the term-end course evaluation.
courses.required_readings: The course outline, including the list of required/recommended readings, will be provided to students in their first week of attendance in this course.

courses.subject: SLPA
courses.title: Professional Development and Ethics II
courses.description: Speech therapy is more than just clinical skills and practice. A competent speech therapist should understand the range of professional issues related to speech-language pathology which may contribute and influence their clinical practice, decision making as well as the profession. Entry-level professional issues, advanced ethical practice and clinical decision making as well as transition to workforce issues are discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to understand the concept of professional development and ethics
courses.course_syllabus: The course outline, including the course syllabus, will be provided to students in their first week of attendance in this course.

courses.subject: SLPA
courses.title: Evidence Based Appraisal for Speech Language Pathology I
courses.description: This course covers basic methodology in research design in the behavioral sciences and basic statistical tools and techniques for analyzing experimental data. Knowledge and procedures of critical appraisal in the practice of evidence-based health care will be introduced. Approaches to evaluate the effectiveness and efficiency of clinical programmes are covered.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:
1. Understand the research methodology for Speech Language Pathology
2. Be able to use basic statistical tools for analyzing experimental data
3. Acquire the knowledge and procedures of critical appraisal in the practice of evidence-based health care
courses.course_syllabus: The course outline, including the course syllabus, will be provided to students in their first week of attendance in this course.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are encouraged to communicate with the instructors to provide comments and/or feedback on the course. Students are requested to participate in the term-end course evaluation.
courses.required_readings: The course outline, including the list of required/recommended readings, will be provided to students in their first week of attendance in this course.

courses.subject: SLPA
courses.title: Test Development & Assessment Approaches
courses.description: Assessment is a major component in the study of speech-language pathology. This course will introduce key assessment approaches including norm-referenced, criterion-referenced and dynamic tests. Students will learn about the characteristics of each type of assessment, the meaningful interpretation of test scores as well as the potential application in communication disorders in culturally and linguistically diverse populations. Students will learn major procedures in test development from item construction to data collection to evaluation. Critical concepts of psychometric properties of test evaluation will be covered.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:
1. Demonstrate the ability to identify and locate major anatomical structures related respiration, swallowing, speech, language and hearing
2. Explain the physiological function(s) of anatomical structures related to respiration, swallowing, speech, language and hearing
3. Demonstrate a basic understanding of the nervous system and neural sub-systems
4. Understand and explain the physiological relationship(s) between the nervous system and the relevant neural structures related to speech.
courses.course_syllabus: Please refer to the course outline
courses.feedback_evaluation: Please refer to the course outline
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline
courses.recommended_readings: Please refer to the course outline

courses.subject: SLPA
courses.title: Anatomy and Physiology of Speech, Language and Hearing
courses.description: An introduction to the anatomical and physiological aspects to the auditory, respiratory, laryngeal, and swallowing systems is provided. There will be lectures, in-class activities and laboratory sessions. Students will be exposed to anatomy and physiology software, 3D models and the 3D Anatomage Table (life-sized visualization system) to enhance learning.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology and BA Bimodal Bilingual Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:
1. Demonstrate the ability to identify and locate major anatomical structures related respiration, swallowing, speech, language and hearing
2. Explain the physiological function(s) of anatomical structures related to respiration, swallowing, speech, language and hearing
3. Demonstrate a basic understanding of the nervous system and neural sub-systems
4. Understand and explain the physiological relationship(s) between the nervous system and the relevant neural structures related to speech.

courses.subject: SLPA
courses.title: Fluency Disorders
courses.description: This course discusses the nature, symptoms, and prevalence of stuttering disorders. Students will be provided with the basic knowledge on assessing, counselling, and treating persons with fluency disorders.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:
1. Understand the nature, symptoms, and prevalence of fluency disorders
2. Be able to assess and manage persons with fluency disorders

Mr YU Shing, 
Professor LAW Thomas Ka Tung

courses.description: This course discusses the nature, symptoms and prevalence of voice and laryngeal disorders. Students will be provided with the basic knowledge on assessing, counselling, and treating persons with voice and laryngeal disorders.

courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:

courses.subject: SLPA
courses.title: Acquired Neurogenic Communication Disorders
courses.description: This course gives an overview of the human's nervous system in terms of its structure and function. The primary focus is on the nervous system in the reception and expression of speech and language. Speech and language disorders resulting from cardiovascular and cerebrovascular damage due to trauma, disease and adventitious central nervous system (CNS) events will be included. Evaluation and management of the related language, speech and cognitive disorders will be covered.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:
1. Understand the structure and function of the humanâ€™s nervous system
2. Evaluate and manage the related language, speech and cognitive disorders

courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are encouraged to communicate with the instructors to provide comments and/or feedback on the course. Students are requested to participate in the term-end course evaluation.

courses.subject: SLPA
courses.title: Multimodal Communication
courses.description: The course introduces the methodologies and technologies used to promote the development of communication skills in individuals with various kinds of communication disorders including cerebral palsy and multiple disabilities. The impact of augmentative communication in social interaction, personal growth, educational & vocational opportunities, as well as other aspects of human interaction will be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:
1. Describe and implement assessment and management strategies for individuals with complex communication needs
2. Recognize the characteristics of common congenital and acquired disabilities and their impact of communication, and design multimodal communication systems accordingly
3. Recognize the role of speech-language pathologists among members of the multidisciplinary team in managing clients with complex communication needs
courses.course_syllabus: Please refer to the course outline
courses.feedback_evaluation: Please refer to the course outline
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline

courses.subject: SLPA
courses.title: Language Disorders from Infancy to Adolescence I
courses.description: The course focuses on language disorders from infancy to adolescence. The course will expose students to assessment methods and techniques encompassing the three main language domains of form, content and use with direct hands-on experience with relevant and specified standardised and non-standardised assessments. The range of treatment approaches will be covered with an emphasis on evidence-based treatment approaches and practice. Students will also be exposed to person-centred functional goals directly addressing the WHO ICF (International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health) framework. Teaching and learning enhancement techniques will include case studies, videos and role play.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:
1. Identify components of language (form, content and use) and be able to describe and give examples of the typical developmental milestones and skills for each language component at major stages: infancy (pre-linguistic stage), toddlerhood, pre-school, school-age and adolescence.
2. Identify the relevant standardized assessments for each major stage and domains and discuss other types of assessment methods.
3. Describe the different types of intervention approaches and identify evidence-based treatment approaches for language components and/or major stages.
4. Identify and describe considerations in the assessment and treatment of DLD (developmental language disorder), language disorders associated with different conditions (e.g. ASD), bilingual children and in CALD (culturally and linguistically different children).
courses.course_syllabus: Please refer to the course outline
courses.feedback_evaluation: Please refer to the course outline
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline

courses.subject: SLPA
courses.title: Speech Sound Disorders
courses.description: This course covers children's acquisition of speech, articulatory foundations of speech, transcription of speech and classification and causes of speech sound disorders. The course will introduce students to the different types of speech sound disorders, differentiating between those involving phonology (e.g. phonological impairment) and those related to motor speech (e.g. articulation impairment). Students will also be exposed to person-centred functional goals directly addressing the WHO ICF (International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health) framework. The range of treatment approaches will be taught with an emphasis on evidence-based treatment approaches for the different types of SSD. Teaching and learning enhancement techniques will include case studies, videos and role play/simulations.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:
1. Describe the different types of speech sound disorders in children and classification systems used within the field.
2. Identify appropriate assessment procedure(s) and assessment components and apply the relevant analyses to children's speech.
3. Discuss the different ways of identifying appropriate goals and identify the most appropriate intervention approach based on the available evidence-base.
4. Identify considerations for assessing and treating speech sound disorders in selected populations.
courses.course_syllabus: Please refer to the course outline
courses.feedback_evaluation: Please refer to the course outline
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline

courses.subject: SLPA
courses.title: Craniofacial Anomalies
courses.description: The course will cover craniofacial conditions, focusing on cleft lip and palate and craniofacial dysostosis.Students will learn how to undertaken a comprehensive perceptual assessment of cleft palate speech and velopharyngeal dysfunction using a standardized speech sampling protocol and listening protocol. Students will be exposed to treatment of cleft palate speech from early intervention to adulthood. The course will also cover instrumental assessment of cleft palate speech and velopharyngeal function. Students will also be exposed to primary and secondary (velopharyngeal) surgery in this client population and the inter-professional working paradigm within a cranofacial clinical service.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:
1. Identify and describe the roles of different professionals within a craniofacial team
2. Identify and describe perceptual and instrumental assessment methods in cleft lip and palate and velopharyngeal dysfunction
3. Identify and describe specific treatment approaches in CLP
courses.course_syllabus: Please refer to the course outline
courses.feedback_evaluation: Please refer to the course outline
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline

courses.subject: SLPA
courses.title: Aural Rehabilitation and Audiology

meetings.instructor:
Dr. NG Hoi Yee Iris, 
Ms LAM Yuk Chau

courses.description: This course will cover the fundamental audiological evaluations as well as a brief introduction on more advanced approaches. Students will learn about interpretation of audiological reports, major principles of speech perception assessment and various approaches of aural (re)habilitation for populations ranging from infants to older adults.

courses.subject: SLPA
courses.title: Dysphagia
courses.description: This course aims to provide students with the fundamental knowledge of swallowing, dysphagia assessment and management. This course aims to equip students with entry-level skills to assess and manage dysphagia across all age range, in particular the adult population.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:
1. Describe the anatomy and physiology in swallowing
2. Describe the clinical presentation of dysphagia across phases of swallowing
3. Recognize a range of underlying diseases that can lead to dysphagia and describe the corresponding
presentation
4. Differentiate and apply a range of assessments, management and/or therapeutic approaches for dysphagia
courses.course_syllabus: Please refer to the course outline
courses.feedback_evaluation: Please refer to the course outline
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline

courses.subject: SLPA
courses.title: Dysphagia (II)
courses.description: This course aims to provide students with more in-depth knowledge of swallowing, dysphagia assessment and management. This course aims to equip students with entry-level knowledge on instrumental assessment such as Fibreoptic Endoscopic Evaluation of Swallowing (FEES), Videofluoroscopic Swallow Study (VFSS) and ultrasound. It also equips students with knowledge of dysphagia in special populations such as patients with tracheostomy.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
Pre-requisite: SLPA5210
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the completion of this course, students are expected to:

* Identify and describe basic terms and clinical utility of the different types of instrumentation used in the assessment, diagnosis and management of dysphagia.
* Demonstrate basic skills in the analysis and interpretation of instumental data related to swaloowing disorders for the purposes of diagnosis and management.
* Recognize the impact of tracheostomy in patients on speech and swallowing function
courses.course_syllabus:
| **Topic** | **Contents/ fundamental concepts** |
| --- | --- |
| Instrumental assessment of swallowing | * Overview of instrumental assessment of swallowing * Indications and contraindications of instrumental assessment of swallowing * Different instrumental assessments |
| Tracheostomy and speech/swallowing function | * Overview of tracheostomy * Impact of tracheostomy on speech function * Impact of tracheostomy on swallowing function * Assessment and management of patients with a tracheostomy |
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students' views and comments are highly valued and appreciated on course content, teaching pedagogies and assessment approaches. An end of term questionnaire will be provided to students for course evaluation. Students are most welcome to provide feedback and suggestions via emails, office hour discussion, or appointment meetings with the course instructors. Students may also provide course-specific feedback during end-of-semester student-teacher meetings.
courses.required_readings:
Shaker, R., Easterling, C., Belafsky, P.C., & Postma, G.N. (Eds.). (2013). *Manual of diagnostic and therapeutic techniques for disorders of deglutition*. New York: Springer NY. (Online access).

Skoretz, S. A., Anger, N., Wellman, L., Takai, O., & Empey, A. (2020). A systematic review of tracheostomy modifications and swallowing in adults. *Dysphagia*, 35, 935-947.
courses.recommended_readings: Langmore, S.E. (2011). *Endoscopic evaluation and treatment of swallowing disorders*. New York: Thieme.

courses.subject: SLPA
courses.title: Paediatric Feeding and Swallowing Disorders

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03

courses.description: The course provides students with comprehensive knowledge of paediatric feeding and swallowing assessment and management. Content of anatomy, normal development, paediatric neurodevelopment and aero-digestive system, clinical swallowing and feeding assessment, and management will be covered. Through a combination of lectures, team-based learning, case studies, and practical exercises, students will develop a deep understanding of the complexities surrounding paediatric feeding and swallowing disorders and acquire the necessary skills to assess and manage these conditions effectively.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
Pre-requisite: SLPA5210
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the completion of this course, students are expected to:

* Demonstrate an in-depth understanding of paediatric feeding and swallowing disorders, including the anatomical and developmental aspects.
* Evaluate and interpret clinical assessment of paediatric swallowing and feeding disorders.
* Develop evidence-based management strategies for paediatric feeding and swallowing disorders.
courses.course_syllabus:
| Topic | Contents/ fundamental concepts |
| --- | --- |
| Anatomical and Developmental Aspects for Paediatric Feeding and Swallowing Disorders | * Anatomy of the paediatric swallowing mechanism * Normal development of swallowing and feeding skills in infants and children * Aerodigestive systems in children |
| Clinical Assessment for Paediatric Feeding and Swallowing Disorders | * Overview of clinical assessment methods for paediatric feeding and swallowing disorders * Evaluation of oral motor skills, coordination, and sensory aspects * Identification of signs and symptoms of swallowing difficulties in children * Assessment of risk factors and potential complications in paediatric population |
| Evidence-Based Management for Paediatic Feeding and Swallowing Disorders | * Principles of evidence-based practice in managing paediatric feeding and swallowing disorders * Therapeutic interventions and strategies for improving feeding and swallowing function * Collaboration with interdisciplinary teams, families, and caregivers in the management process |
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students' views and comments are highly valued and appreciated on course content, teaching pedagogies and assessment approaches. An end of term questionnaire will be provided to students for course evaluation. Students are most welcome to provide feedback and suggestions via emails, office hour discussion, or appointment meetings with the course instructors. Students may also provide course-specific feedback during end-of-semester student-teacher meetings.
courses.required_readings:
Arvedson, J. C., Brodsky, L., & Lefton-Greif, M. A. (Eds.). (2019). *Pediatric swallowing and feeding: Assessment and management*. Plural Publishing.

Crary, M. A., & Groher, M. E. (2016). *Dysphagia: clinical management in adults and children*. Elsevier Health Sciences.
courses.recommended_readings: Wolf, L. S., & Glass, R. P. (1992). *Feeding and swallowing disorders in infancy: Assessment and management*. Pro-Ed.

courses.subject: SLPA
courses.title: Complex Case Management in Speech-Language Pathology
courses.description:
This course aims to prepare students to manage complex cases as an entry-level speech language pathologist. Clinical management is more complex not only when clients/patients are presented with competing communication and swallowing needs but also when their conditions interact with other challenges, such as cultural, moral, ethical, legal, and service delivery issues etc.

This course adopts a team-based learning approach to allow students to reflect, discuss and problem solve to generate clinical decisions on various complex case scenarios.

Students are required to integrate the knowledge they acquired on a range of practice areas in speech language pathology while considering issues including but not limited to medical ethics, evidence-based practice, ICF model, person-centered care, interprofessional collaborative practice and culturally responsive practice.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
courses.course_syllabus:
| Topic | Contens/ fundamental concepts |
| --- | --- |
| Issues related to complex cases in speech-language pathology | * Multifactorial nature of complex cases * Clinical issues associated with complex cases * Ethical, moral, legal issues related complex cases * Social and cultrual issuses related to complex cases * Assessment and management for complex cases |
| Clinical decision-making models for complex cases | * Clinical decision-making models relevant to complex cases |
| Professional practice principles in complex cases | * Professional practice principles relevant to complex cases e.g. evidence-based practice, health care ethics, ICF model, person-centered care, interprofessional collaborative practice, cultrually responsive practice etc. |
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students' views and comments are highly valued and appreciated on course content, teaching pedagogies and assessment approaches. An end of term questionnaire will be provided to students for course evaluation. Students are most welcome to provide feedback and suggestions via emails, office hour discussion, or appointment meetings with the course instructors. Students may also provide course-specific feedback during end-of-semester student-teacher meetings.
courses.required_readings:
Bea Staley, Ellen Hickey, David Rule, Helen Barrett, Claire Salter, Rachael Gibson & David Rochus (2021) Speech-language pathology and ethical practice in global contexts, International Journal of Speech-Language Pathology, 23:1, 15-25, DOI: 10.1080/17549507.2020.1743358

Dudding, Carol C. and Pfeiffer, Danika L. (2018) "Cinical Decision-making in Speech-Language Pathology Graduate Students: Quantitative Findings," Teaching and Learning in Communication Sciences & Disorders: Vol. 2: Iss. 1, Article 2. DOI: doi.org/10.30707/TLCSD2.1Dudding

courses.title: Introduction to Work Integrated Learning and Clinical Practice
courses.description: The course is designed to provide students with basic clinical skills to prepare for clinical practice. Students will acquire basic and generic clinical skills in relation to speech language pathology through seminars, workshops, and simulated learning.

courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to acquire basic generic clinical management skills for clinical practice, including case-history taking, clinical interaction skills, reporting skills and documentation.

courses.description: The course is designed to provide students with experiential learning for them to develop the required clinical skills in managing clients with various communication disorders. courses.subject: SLPA
courses.title: Work Integrated Learning and Special Clinic II
courses.description: The course is designed to provide students with experiential learning for them to develop the required clinical skills in managing clients with various communication disorders. Students will be trained to manage, under supervision, paediatric and adult clients in various settings including clinics, schools, health care organizations, and hospitals.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to apply theories from academic learning into workplace practice through various work-integrated learning activities and be exposed to advanced clinical practice.
courses.course_syllabus: Please refer to the course outline
courses.feedback_evaluation: Please refer to the course outline
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline

courses.subject: SLPA
courses.title: Phonetics and Phonology for Speech-Language-Pathology
courses.description: This course introduces students to a unified approach to language as a complex structure represented in the minds of its speakers. Empirical linguistic data will be drawn across languages to enable students to understand the intimate relation between language and the human mind. On the basis of this understanding, students are led to explore the core areas of linguistics. The exploration starts with natural language sound systems and phonological components of grammar. These will be explained with basic concepts and recent theoretical advances in linguistic studies alongside new findings in language acquisition. Students will learn to apply these concepts and ideas to tackle linguistic problems.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
courses.course_syllabus: Please refer to the course outline
courses.feedback_evaluation: Please refer to the course outline
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline

courses.subject: SLPA
courses.title: Syntax and Semantics for Speech-Language-Pathology
courses.description: Taking a modular approach to the language system, this course examines the morphological, semantic and syntactic components of the grammar, as well as the interaction among them. The lectures are intended to provide students with a solid grounding in basic linguistic concepts, which will enable them to tackle linguistic problems, and formulate their own analyses to prepare them for further studies in the discipline. A wide range of data will be discussed to develop studentsâ€™ sensitivity toward linguistic phenomena with systematic properties in form, meaning and structure.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:
1. Develop sensitivity toward language phenomena with systematic properties in form, meaning and structure.
2. Attain an understanding that individual languages are specific realizations of Universal Grammar.
3. Build foundations in syntax (e.g. constituent structure and basic syntactic operations motivated by morphology and semantics) and semantics (e.g. predicate-argument, reference, tense~aspect, proposition), and their interfaces (through morphology), to pave the way for further studies in the program.
4. Gain basic problem solving and analytical skills in the above areas to facilitate studies in more advanced courses.
courses.course_syllabus: Please refer to the course outline
courses.feedback_evaluation: Please refer to the course outline
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline

courses.subject: SLPA
courses.title: Language Acquisition for Speech-Language-Pathology
courses.description: The acquisition of first language by children has been considered a remarkable feat. How do children accomplish this feat so rapidly and effortlessly? What are the stages they go through in mastering the different aspects of language? What does the development of language in children tell us about the human language faculty? These questions will be examined in light of modern linguistic theory, and nativist and interactionist accounts will be compared. Topics in second language acquisition will also be covered. Questions such as how interlanguage grammars develop in adults and the role of the mother tongue in the construction of interlanguage grammar will be addressed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students will be able to understand:
1. The nature of language and its acquisition by humans and primates.
2. The central issues involved in language acquisition inclusive of nature versus nurture, language attainment, cross-linguistic influence, linguistic evidence and the nature of input, as well as linguistic processing.
3. Language phenomena under exceptional circumstances involving language disorder and language attrition.
courses.course_syllabus: Please refer to the course outline
courses.feedback_evaluation: Please refer to the course outline
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline

courses.subject: SLPA
courses.title: Clinical Research

meetings.instructor:
Dr. NG Hoi Yee Iris, 
Mr YU Shing, 
Ms. KWAN Ching Yin, 
Professor FONG Raymond, 
Professor LAW Thomas Ka Tung, 
Professor LEE Yuet Sheung Kathy, 
Professor Valerie Jane PEREIRA

courses.description: The course introduces students on the necessary steps to formulate a research project in relation to a particular aspect of speech pathology. Each student will be guided by a supervisor throughout the processes from literature review, setting up research questions, data collection, applying appropriate research methodology and writing up results.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of the course, students are expected to be able to formulate an independent clinical Research on speech-language pathology.

courses.feedback_evaluation: Please refer to the course outline
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline

courses.description: This course will focus on specific topics in speech-language pathology that are not covered in the regular course offering. These topics will reflect academic needs/interests and faculty expertise. Students are allowed to take this course more than once, and gain the units each time they pass the course. However, students cannot take the course under the same topic twice.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of the course, students are expected to achieve the learning goals stated by the instructor who will be an expert in the course topic.
